Paragraph: Abstract

The secondary structure of ribonucleic acid (RNA) is more stable and accessible
1

in the cell than its tertiary structure, making it essential for functional prediction.
2

Although deep learning has shown promising results in this Ô¨Åeld, current methods
3

suffer from poor generalization and high complexity. In this work, we present
4

RFold, a simple yet effective RNA secondary structure prediction in an end-to-end
5

manner. RFold introduces a decoupled optimization process that decomposes the
6

vanilla constraint satisfaction problem into row-wise and column-wise optimization,
7

simplifying the solving process while guaranteeing the validity of the output.
8

Moreover, RFold adopts attention maps as informative representations instead of
9

designing hand-crafted features. Extensive experiments demonstrate that RFold
10

achieves competitive performance and about eight times faster inference efÔ¨Åciency
11

than the state-of-the-art method.
12

1
Introduction
13

Ribonucleic acid is essential in structural biology for its diverse functional classes [8, 45, 49, 18]. The
14

functions of RNA molecules are determined by their structure [57]. The secondary structure, which
15

contains the nucleotide base pairing information, as shown in Fig. 1, is crucial for the correct functions
16

of RNA molecules [13, 11, 68]. Although experimental assays such as X-ray crystallography [6],
17

nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) [15], and cryogenic electron microscopy [12] can be implemented
18

to determine RNA secondary structure, they suffer from low throughput and expensive cost.
19

graph representation
matrix representation (contact map)

Figure 1: The graph and matrix representation
of an RNA secondary structure example.

Computational RNA secondary structure predic-
20

tion methods have become increasingly popular
21

due to their high efÔ¨Åciency [31]. Currently, these
22

methods can be broadly classiÔ¨Åed into two cate-
23

gories [50, 14, 55, 60]: (i) comparative sequence
24

analysis and (ii) single sequence folding algorithm.
25

Comparative sequence analysis determines the sec-
26

ondary structure conserved among homologous se-
27

quences but the limited known RNA families hin-
28

der its development [35, 36, 28, 22, 21, 16, 43].
29

Researchers thus resort to single RNA sequence
30

folding algorithms that do not need multiple se-
31

quence alignment information. A classical cate-
32

gory of computational RNA folding algorithms is
33

to use dynamic programming (DP) that assumes the
34

secondary structure is a result of energy minimiza-
35

tion [3, 44, 39, 73, 42, 10]. However, energy-based
36

approaches usually require a nested structure, which ignores some biologically essential structures
37

such as pseudoknots, i.e., non-nested base pairs [5, 54, 70], as shown in Fig. 2. Since predicting
38

secondary structures with pseudoknots under the energy minimization framework has shown to be
39

hard and NP-complete [66, 14], deep learning techniques are introduced as an alternative approach.
40

secondary structures.

Attempts to overcome the limitations of energy-
41

based methods have motivated deep learning meth-
42

ods in the absence of DP. SPOT-RNA [55] is a
43

seminal work that ensembles ResNet [24] and
44

LSTM [25] to identify molecular features. SPOT-
45

RNA does not constrain the output space into valid
46

RNA secondary structures, which degrades its gen-
47

eralization ability [32]. E2Efold [5] employs an
48

unrolled algorithm for constrained programming
49

that post-processes the network output to satisfy
50

the constraints. E2Efold introduces a convex relax-
51

ation to make the optimization tractable, leading
52

to possible constraint violations and poor general-
53

ization ability [53, 14]. Developing an appropriate
54

optimization that forces the output to be valid be-
55

comes an important issue. Apart from the optimization problem, state-of-the-art approaches require
56

hand-crafted features and introduce the pre-processing step for such features, which is inefÔ¨Åcient and
57

needs expert knowledge. CDPfold [72] develops a matrix representation based on sequence pairing
58

that reÔ¨Çects the implicit matching between bases. UFold [14] follows the exact post-process mecha-
59

nism as E2Efold and uses hand-crafted features from CDPfold with U-Net [51] model architecture to
60

improve the performance.
61

Although promising, current deep learning methods on RNA secondary structure prediction have
62

been distressed by: (1) the optimization process that is complicated and poor in generalization and
63

(2) the data pre-processing that requires expensive complexity and expert knowledge. In this paper,
64

we present RFold, a simple yet effective RNA secondary structure prediction method in an end-to-end
65

manner. SpeciÔ¨Åcally, we introduce a decoupled optimization process that decomposes the vanilla
66

constraint satisfaction problem into row-wise and column-wise optimization, simplifying the solving
67

process while guaranteeing the validity of the output. Besides, we adopt attention maps as informative
68

representations to automatically learn the pair-wise interactions of the nucleotide bases instead of
69

using hand-crafted features to perform data pre-processing. We conduct extensive experiments to
70

compare RFold with state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets and show the superior
71

performance of our proposed method. Moreover, RFold has faster inference efÔ¨Åciency than those
72

methods due to its simplicity.
73

2
Related work
74

2.1
Comparative Sequence Analysis
75

Comparative sequence analysis determines base pairs conserved among homologous sequences [55,
76

17, 28, 36, 35, 19, 20]. ILM [52] combines thermodynamic and mutual information content scores.
77

Sankoff [27] merges the sequence alignment and maximal-pairing folding methods [46]. Dy-
78

nalign [41] and Carnac [62, 47] are the subsequent variants of Sankoff algorithms. RNA forester [26]
79

introduces a tree alignment model for global and local alignments. However, the limited number of
80

known RNA families [21, 16, 43] impedes the development of comparative methods.
81

2.2
Energy-based Folding Algorithms
82

When the secondary structure consists only of nested base pairing, dynamic programming can
83

efÔ¨Åciently predict the structure by minimizing energy. Early works in this category include Vienna
84

RNAfold [39], Mfold [73], RNAstructure [42], and CONTRAfold [10]. Faster implementations that
85

speed up dynamic programming have been proposed, such as Vienna RNAplfold [4], LocalFold [37],
86

and LinearFold [30]. However, these methods cannot accurately predict secondary structures with
87

pseudoknots, as predicting the lowest free energy structures with pseudoknots is NP-complete [40],
88

making it difÔ¨Åcult to improve performance.
89

2.3
Learning-based Folding Algorithms
90

SPOT-RNA [55] is a seminal work that employs deep learning for RNA secondary structure predic-
91

tion. SPOT-RNA2 [56] improves its predecessor by using evolution-derived sequence proÔ¨Åles and
92

mutational coupling. Inspired by Raptor-X [65] and SPOT-Contact [23], SPOT-RNA uses ResNet
93

and bidirectional LSTM with a sigmoid function to output the secondary structures. MXfold [1] is
94

also an early work that combines support vector machines and thermodynamic models. CDPfold [72],
95

DMFold [64], and MXFold2 [53] integrate deep learning techniques with energy-based methods.
96

E2Efold [5] takes a remarkable step in constraining the output to be valid by learning unrolled
97

algorithms. However, its relaxation for making the optimization tractable may violate the structural
98

constraints. UFold [14] further introduces U-Net model architecture to improve performance.
99

3
Preliminaries and Backgrounds
100

3.1
Preliminaries
101

The primary structure of RNA is the ordered linear sequence of bases, which is typically represented
102

as a string of letters. Formally, an RNA sequence can be represented as X ‚Äú px1, ..., xLq, where xi P
103

tA, U, C, Gu denotes one of the four bases, i.e., Adenine (A), Uracil (U), Cytosine (C), and Guanine
104

(G). The secondary structure of RNA is a contact map represented as a matrix M P t0, 1uLÀÜL, where
105

Mij ‚Äú 1 if the i-th and j-th bases are paired. In the RNA secondary structure prediction problem, we
106

aim to obtain a model with learnable parameters Œò that learns a mapping FŒò : X √û√ë M by exploring
107

the interactions between bases. Here, we decompose the mapping FŒò into two sub-mappings as:
108

FŒò :‚Äú HŒ∏h Àù GŒ∏g,
(1)

where HŒ∏h : X √û√ë H, GŒ∏g : H √û√ë M are mappings parameterized by Œ∏h and Œ∏g, respectively.
109

H P RLÀÜL is regarded as the unconstrained output of neural networks.
110

3.2
Backgrounds
111

It is worth noting that there are hard constraints on the formation of RNA secondary structure,
112

meaning that certain types of pairing are not available [59]. Such constraints [5] can be formally
113

described as follows:
114

‚Ä¢ (a) Only three types of nucleotide combinations can form base pairs: B :‚Äú tAU, UAu Y
115

tGC, CGu Y tGU, UGu. For any base pair xixj where xixj R B, Mij ‚Äú 0.
116

‚Ä¢ (b) No sharp loops within three bases. For any adjacent bases, there can be no pairing between
117

them, i.e., @|i ¬¥ j| ƒè 3, Mij ‚Äú 0.
118

‚Ä¢ (c) There can be at most one pair for each base, i.e., @i, ≈ôL
j‚Äú1 Mij ƒè 1.
119

The available space of valid secondary structures is all symmetric matrices P t0, 1uLÀÜL that satisfy
120

the above three constraints. The Ô¨Årst two constraints can be satisÔ¨Åed easily. We deÔ¨Åne a constraint
121

matrix ƒé
M as: ƒé
Mij :‚Äú 1 if xixj P B and |i ¬¥ j| ƒõ 4, and ƒé
Mij :‚Äú 0 otherwise. By element-wise
122

multiplication of the network output and the constraint matrix ƒé
M, invalid pairs are masked.
123

The critical issue in obtaining a valid RNA secondary structure is the third constraint, i.e., processing
124

the network output to create a symmetric binary matrix that only allows a single "1" to exist in each
125

row and column. There are different strategies for dealing with this issue.
126

is a typical kind of method that imposes minor constraints. It takes the original output
127

of neural networks H and directly applies the Sigmoid function, assigning a value of 1 to those
128

greater than 0.5 and 0 to those less than 0.5. This process can be represented as:
129

4.3
Row-Col Softmax

176

178

179

H separately, as

5
Experiments
220

We conduct experiments to compare our proposed RFold with state-of-the-art and commonly used
221

methods in the Ô¨Åeld of RNA secondary structure prediction. Multiple experimental settings are
222

taken into account, including standard RNA secondary structure prediction, generalization evaluation,
223

large-scale benchmark evaluation, and inference time comparison. Ablation studies are also presented.
224

Datasets
We use three benchmark datasets: (i) RNAStralign [61], one of the most comprehensive
225

collections of RNA structures, is composed of 37,149 structures from 8 RNA types; (ii) ArchiveII [57],
226

a widely used benchmark dataset in classical RNA folding methods, containing 3,975 RNA structures
227

from 10 RNA types; (iii) bpRNA [55], is a large scale benchmark dataset, containing 102,318
228

structures from 2,588 RNA types.
229

Baselines
We compare our proposed RFold with baselines including energy-based folding methods
230

such as Mfold [73], RNAsoft [2], RNAfold [39], RNAstructure [42], CONTRAfold [10], Con-
231

textfold [71], and LinearFold [30]; learning-based folding methods such as SPOT-RNA [55], Exter-
232

nafold [67], E2Efold [5], MXfold2 [53], and UFold [14].
233

Metrics
We evaluate the performance by precision, recall, and F1 score, which are deÔ¨Åned as:
234

Precision ‚Äú
TP
TP ` FP, Recall ‚Äú
TP
TP ` FN, F1 ‚Äú 2 Precision ¬® Recall

Precision ` Recall,
(19)

where TP, FP, and FN denote true positive, false positive and false negative, respectively.
235

Implementation details
Following [14], we train the model for 100 epochs with the Adam opti-
236

mizer. The learning rate is 0.001, and the batch size is 1 for sequences with different lengths.
237

5.1
Standard RNA Secondary Structure Prediction
238

Following [5], we split the RNAStralign dataset
239

into training, validation, and testing sets by strat-
240

iÔ¨Åed sampling to ensure every set has all RNA
241

types. We report the experimental results in Ta-
242

ble 1. It can be seen that energy-based methods
243

achieve relatively weak F1 scores ranging from
244

0.420 to 0.633. Learning-based folding algo-
245

rithms like E2Efold and UFold can signiÔ¨Åcantly
246

improve performance by large margins, while
247

RFold obtain even better performance among all
248

the metrics. Moreover, RFold obtains about 8%
249

higher precision than the state-of-the-art method.
250

This phenomenon suggests that our proposed de-
251

coupled optimization is strict to satisfy all the
252

hard constraints for predicting valid structures.
253

5.2
Generalization Evaluation
254

To verify the generalization ability of our proposed RFold, we directly evaluate the performance
255

on another benchmark dataset ArchiveII using the pre-trained model on the RNAStralign training
256

dataset. Following [5], we exclude RNA sequences in ArchiveII that have overlapping RNA types
257

with the RNAStralign dataset for a fair comparison. The results are reported in Table 2.
258

It can be seen that traditional methods achieve F1 scores in the range of 0.545 to 0.842. Among
259

the state-of-the-art methods, RFold attains the highest F1 score. It is noteworthy that RFold has a
260

relatively lower recall metric and signiÔ¨Åcantly higher precision metric. This phenomenon may be
261

due to the strict constraints imposed by RFold. Although none of the current learning-based methods
262

can meet all the constraints presented in Sec. 3.2, the predictions made by RFold are guaranteed to
263

be valid. Therefore, RFold may cover fewer pairwise interactions, resulting in a lower recall metric.
264

Nonetheless, the highest F1 score indicates the excellent generalization ability of RFold.
265

5.3
Large-scale Benchmark Evaluation
266

The large-scale benchmark dataset bpRNA has a Ô¨Åxed training set (TR0), evaluation set (VL0),
267

and testing set (TS0). Following [55, 53, 14], we train the model in bpRNA-TR0 and evaluate the
268

performance on bpRNA-TS0 by using the best model learned from bpRNA-VL0. We summarize
269

the evaluation results in Table 3. It can be seen that RFold signiÔ¨Åcantly improves the previous
270

state-of-the-art method SPOT-RNA by 4.0% in the F1 score.
271

Following [14], we conduct an experiment
272

on long-range interactions. The bpRNA-TS0
273

dataset contains more versatile RNA sequences
274

of different lengths and various types, which can
275

be a reliable evaluation. Given a sequence of
276

length L, the long-range base pairing is deÔ¨Åned
277

as the paired and unpaired bases with intervals
278

longer than L{2. As shown in Table 4, RFold
279

performs unexpectedly well on these long-range
280

base pairing predictions. We can also Ô¨Ånd that
281

UFold performs better in long-range cases than
282

the complete cases. The possible reason may
283

come from the U-Net model architecture that
284

learns multi-scale features. RFold signiÔ¨Åcantly
285

improves UFold in all the metrics by large mar-
286

gins, demonstrating its strong predictive ability.
287

5.4
Inference Time Comparison
288

We compared the running time of various methods
289

for predicting RNA secondary structures using the
290

RNAStralign testing set with the same experimen-
291

tal setting as in [14]. The results are presented in
292

Table 5, which shows the average inference time
293

per sequence. The fastest energy-based method is
294

LinearFold, which takes an average of about 0.43s
295

for each sequence. The previous learning-based
296

baseline, UFold, takes about 0.16s. RFold has the
297

highest inference speed, costing only about 0.02s
298

per sequence. In particular, RFold is about eight
299

times faster than UFold and sixteen times faster than
300

MXfold2. The fast inference time of RFold is due
301

to its simple sequence-to-map transformation.
302

5.5
Ablation Study
303

Decoupled Optimization
To validate the effectiveness of our proposed decoupled optimization,
304

we conduct an experiment that replaces them with other strategies. The results are summarized in
305

Table 6, where RFold-E and RFold-S denote our model with the strategies of E2Efold and SPOT-RNA,
306

respectively. We ignore the recent UFold because it follows exactly the same strategy as E2Efold.
307

We also report the validity which is a sample-level metric evaluating whether all the constraints are
308

satisÔ¨Åed. Though RFold-E has comparable performance in the Ô¨Årst three metrics with ours, many
309

of its predicted structures are invalid. The strategy of SPOT-RNA has incorporated no constraint
310

that results in its low validity. Moreover, its strategy seems to not Ô¨Åt our model well, which may be
311

caused by the simplicity of our RFold model.
312

Seq2map Attention
We also conduct an experiment to evaluate the proposed Seq2map attention.
313

We replace the Seq2map attention with the hand-crafted features from UFold and the outer concate-
314

nation from SPOT-RNA, which are denoted as RFold-U and RFold-SS, respectively. In addition to
315

performance metrics, we also report the average inference time for each RNA sequence to evaluate
316

the model complexity. We summarize the result in Table 7. It can be seen that RFold-U takes much
317

more inference time than our RFold and RFold-SS due to the heavy computational cost when loading
318

and learning from hand-crafted features. Moreover, it is surprising to Ô¨Ånd that RFold-SS has a little
319

better performance than RFold-U, with the least inference time for its simple outer concatenation
320

operation. However, neither RFold-U nor RFold-SS can provide informative representations.
321

5.6
Visualization
322

We visualize two examples predicted by RFold and UFold in Fig. 6. The corresponding F1 scores are
323

denoted at the bottom of each plot. The Ô¨Årst secondary structures is a simple example of a nested
324

structure. It can be seen that UFold may fail in such a case. The second secondary structures is much
325

more difÔ¨Åcult that contains over 300 bases of the non-nested structure. While UFold fails in such a
326

complex case, RFold can predict the structure accurately. Due to the limited space, we provide more
327

visualization comparisons in Appendix D.

6
Conclusion
329

In this study, we present RFold, a simple yet effective learning-based model for RNA secondary
330

structure prediction. We propose decoupled optimization to replace the complicated post-processing
331

strategies while incorporating constraints for the output. Seq2map attention is proposed for sequence-
332

to-map transformation, which can automatically learn informative representations from a single
333

sequence without extensive pre-processing operations. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that
334

RFold achieves competitive performance with faster inference speed. We hope RFold can provide a
335

new perspective for efÔ¨Åcient RNA secondary structure prediction.
336
